entry.title: Re: How to subscribe or fetch data from solace to CPI using AEM Adapter : part-5
entry.content:
Hi Pavan

Great article again, as with all your previous ones regarding AEM!

One remark: please note that you need to end processing with an ERROR END event if you want to have retries; otherwise, you will finish with a COMPLETED status.

Another aspect to consider is how to distinguish transient errors from permanent ones. Listing all errors and assigning each to one of these two categories is impossible, given that some HTTP errors cannot be definitively classified as temporary. We can refine the value mapping over time, as it also depends on the target application's behavior. The bottom line I've used for my integrations: it's better to retry data errors than to escalate connectivity ones.

best regards

Mateusz

entry.title: #SITSP2025 🎤Abertura Oficial do SAP Inside Track São Paulo 2025
entry.content:
João Secco Anfitrião da abertura e profissional envolvido em diversas frentes da comunidade SAP. Apresentou os patrocinadores e a estrutura do evento com leveza e humor.

Eduardo Savino – Coordenador do curso de Ciência da Computação da PUC-SP, que sediou o evento. Com longa trajetória acadêmica, contribui com formações em engenharia, ciência da computação e design.

Luciano Casado – Diretor da GFX Consultoria. Representa uma consultoria nordestina especializada em SAP, com foco em formação de talentos e compromisso na entrega de projetos.

João Seon – Representante comercial da TakOnix, apresentou soluções no-code para SAP e compartilhou casos de sucesso.

Lígera Baceto – Profissional da Accenture, com atuação em SAP e outras plataformas, ressaltou a solidez e abrangência da Accenture no mercado global de tecnologia.

Descrição da palestra

A abertura do evento foi marcada por uma recepção calorosa, com agradecimentos aos participantes, patrocinadores e à PUC-SP. Foram apresentadas as divisões do público (funcional e técnico), a logística do evento, e breves falas institucionais dos patrocinadores: GFX, TakOnix e Accenture. Os representantes destacaram suas soluções, valores institucionais e os vínculos com a comunidade SAP.

O SAP Inside Track São Paulo 2025 teve início com uma atmosfera acolhedora e bem-humorada, conduzida por João Circo, que contextualizou o evento e distribuiu agradecimentos à comunidade, patrocinadores e à PUC-SP, anfitriã do encontro.

O público foi dividido em dois grupos principais: um mais funcional, com gerentes de projeto, PMOs e curiosos sobre o ecossistema SAP, alocado no andar superior; e outro mais técnico, composto por desenvolvedores ABAPs, direcionado ao espaço inferior, carinhosamente apelidado de “calabouço”. Essa separação permitiu a adequação dos conteúdos e experiências ao perfil dos participantes.

O professor Eduardo Savino, da PUC-SP, apresentou as credenciais da universidade e reforçou a importância da integração com empresas como a SAP. Destacou a “tropicalização” dos temas abordados no evento, como Pix, Tax Service e reforma tributária – questões diretamente ligadas ao contexto brasileiro e que desafiam a flexibilidade dos sistemas SAP.

Luciano Casado representou a GFX, uma consultoria SAP do Ceará que completa 15 anos. Com ênfase em formação e inovação, Casado destacou a expertise da empresa em SAP Public Edition, mobilidade e desenvolvimento, além de sua cultura de compromisso com a entrega de projetos e valorização de talentos locais.

Na sequência, João Seon apresentou a TakOnix, empresa que fornece soluções no-code voltadas à criação rápida de aplicativos Fiori dentro do SAP S/4HANA. A proposta é eliminar a complexidade de desenvolvimento via ABAP, utilizando uma plataforma que facilita o protótipo e entrega de valor para o cliente.

Encerrando a abertura, Lígera Baceto, da Accenture, descreveu a dimensão global da empresa e sua forte atuação em projetos SAP. Com mais de 800 mil colaboradores no mundo, a Accenture é uma das principais parceiras da SAP e reforça seu compromisso de longa data com clientes e inovação tecnológica.

A fala de abertura concluiu com entusiasmo e expectativa para o restante do evento, anunciando a primeira palestra oficial: “Building Planning SAP” com Thiago Pedroso.

🏅SAP Community Profile ▶️ Linkedin Playlist Palestras #SITSP2025

entry.title: #SITSP2025 🎤Como gerenciar a transformação de negócio de sua empresa e seus clientes
entry.content:
Palestrante

Nome: 🗣️Edson Thomaz

Bio: Profissional com sólida trajetória na SAP, Edson atua como ponto de contato estratégico para soluções de transformação digital e gestão de processos. Com anos de experiência prática e engajamento ativo na comunidade SAP, é conhecido por sua habilidade em traduzir temas técnicos em insights valiosos para áreas de negócio.

Descrição da palestra

A sessão teve como foco central o SAP Business Transformation Management, um conjunto de ferramentas e metodologias que permite gerenciar de forma integrada projetos de transformação digital. Edson trouxe uma visão funcional e estratégica, com foco em como equipes de negócio podem melhorar sua atuação desde o mapeamento de processos até a adoção final de soluções tecnológicas.

*** Link com todas as palestras ***

Resumo da palestra

  • Transformação como processo contínuo
    Edson reforçou que transformação digital não é um projeto pontual, mas uma jornada cíclica de melhoria contínua. A estabilidade pós-GoLive ainda é desafiadora, e muitas falhas decorrem de baixa capacitação ou documentação ineficaz dos processos.

  • Ferramentas SAP para gestão de transformação

    • SAP Signavio: voltado ao mapeamento e otimização de processos de ponta a ponta. Permite desde a mineração automatizada até a modelagem e simulação de cenários.

    • SAP LeanIX: solução de arquitetura corporativa para gestão do portfólio de aplicações e alinhamento com capacidades de negócio.

    • SAP Enable Now (ex-WalkMe): foca na adoção digital, guiando usuários dentro de aplicações com fluxos automatizados, reduzindo retrabalho e dúvidas operacionais.

  • Integração das ferramentas e metodologia SAP Activate
    A combinação dessas soluções com a metodologia Activate oferece uma cadeia de ferramentas integradas ("integrated toolchain"), do desenho à capacitação do usuário final. Isso garante rastreabilidade, documentação atualizada e governança contínua.

  • Mineração de processos e análise de desvios
    Ferramentas como o SAP Process Insights permitem capturar dados reais dos sistemas e compará-los ao processo ideal, identificando gargalos, retrabalho e perdas financeiras — tudo com baixa necessidade de consultoria externa.

  • Visualização estratégica para tomada de decisão
    Edson utilizou analogias com projetos arquitetônicos para destacar a importância de visões simples e estratégicas dos processos, permitindo decisões baseadas em valor, não apenas em diagramas técnicos complexos.

  • Inteligência artificial aplicada à gestão de processos
    Ferramentas integradas com IA permitem gerar fluxos BPMN automaticamente a partir de desenhos ou textos descritivos. Isso agiliza a documentação e fomenta a colaboração entre áreas técnicas e de negócio.

Conclusão

A palestra destacou a importância da colaboração entre times técnicos e funcionais para garantir que os projetos de transformação digital sejam bem-sucedidos. A abordagem da SAP, com ferramentas integradas e foco em governança, capacitação e melhoria contínua, mostra-se essencial para empresas que buscam resultados tangíveis em sua jornada para a inovação.

entry.title: #SITSP2025 🎤API na prática para Funcionais
entry.content:
Palestrante

🗣️Késsia Salazar

Com sólida experiência técnica na área de SAP, Késsia é consultora especializada em SAP MM com foco em projetos que envolvem integrações entre sistemas via APIs. Sua trajetória é marcada pela atuação prática, voltada à capacitação de funcionais para entenderem e aplicarem conceitos técnicos de forma eficiente. Participa ativamente de eventos da comunidade SAP, incentivando a presença feminina na tecnologia.

 

Descrição da Palestra

A palestra de Késsia Salazar propôs uma abordagem prática sobre APIs voltada especificamente para consultores funcionais que desejam ou precisam interagir com integrações em projetos SAP. O conteúdo destacou como as APIs são usadas, como podem ser testadas via Postman, os principais conceitos técnicos envolvidos e como fazer uma especificação funcional com conhecimento suficiente para dialogar com desenvolvedores.

*** Link com todas as palestras ***

Resumo do Conteúdo da Palestra

  • Abertura com reflexão sobre diversidade:
    Késsia iniciou destacando o aumento da participação feminina no SAP Inside Track e a importância de incentivar mulheres na área de tecnologia, especialmente em eventos técnicos como o SIT.

  • Objetivo e recado inicial:
    A proposta da palestra foi esclarecer o uso de APIs no contexto funcional, sem aprofundar em configurações técnicas ao vivo devido à limitação de ambiente. A ideia era garantir que qualquer funcional pudesse sair da sessão com base suficiente para atuar com APIs.

  • Introdução ao conceito de API:
    De forma didática, Késsia comparou o funcionamento de APIs ao processo de fazer um pedido em um restaurante, usando o exemplo do iFood para explicar como as solicitações (requests) e respostas (responses) transitam entre cliente, API e servidor.

  • Conceitos técnicos essenciais explicados de forma acessível:

    • Métodos HTTP: GET (consultar), POST (criar), PATCH (alterar).

    • Endpoint: URL de acesso da API.

    • Token de segurança: necessário para criar ou modificar dados.

    • JSON: estrutura que organiza os dados enviados nas requisições.

  • Demonstração com o Postman:

    • Como criar uma Collection e adicionar requisições.

    • Configuração de autenticação com usuário SAP.

    • Envio de GET, POST e PATCH utilizando exemplos práticos.

    • Extração e reutilização do token para alterações.

    • Organização de histórico de testes para facilitar depuração.

  • Importância da biblioteca oficial de APIs SAP:
    Késsia ressaltou a relevância de consultar a biblioteca de APIs (api.sap.com) para validar funcionalidades suportadas, identificar limitações e obter o layout necessário para especificações funcionais.

  • Exemplo prático de especificação funcional:
    A palestrante mostrou como mapear os campos de uma planilha de dados com as tags do JSON da API, facilitando o trabalho de quem irá desenvolver a integração.

  • Conclusão com mensagem estratégica:
    Késsia finalizou reforçando que os profissionais funcionais devem desenvolver conhecimento técnico básico para dialogar melhor com equipes de desenvolvimento e enfrentar os desafios crescentes de integração em projetos SAP.

Considerações Finais

A palestra de Késsia Salazar foi uma das mais relevantes para profissionais que atuam no meio funcional e buscam compreender o universo das APIs sem serem especialistas em desenvolvimento. A didática acessível, os exemplos práticos e o incentivo à autonomia técnica reforçaram a importância de um perfil funcional cada vez mais híbrido no cenário SAP atual.

entry.title: #SITSP2025DEV 🖥️ IA Gen AI
entry.content:
Speaker:
@josh_bentley 
🗣️Josh Blubeard Bentley

Josh Bentley is an SAP Developer Advocate and longtime community leader, known for his charismatic presence, approachable personality, and, of course, his bright blue beard. With a background in IT since the 1990s and a tenure at SAP beginning in 2007, Josh has worked through various phases of tech evolution—from managing Blackberries to promoting GenAI, Kubernetes, and containerized cloud applications. His passion lies in empowering others within the SAP community, particularly developers and functional users seeking to collaborate and grow.

Talk Description:
This session was part storytelling, part community call-to-action. Josh shared his personal career path and quirky anecdotes while diving into how SAP’s mobile, cloud, and community landscapes have changed over time. Though titled around AI, the talk emphasized the enduring value of real-life interaction, collaboration, and community-driven initiatives.

*** Link com todas as palestras ***

Key Takeaways from the Talk:

  • Origin of the Blue Beard:
    Josh opened with the backstory of his iconic beard, initially dyed as a joke to prove he had "personality" on a team. The beard became a conversation starter, a branding tool, and a symbol of his open, engaging approach to tech advocacy.

  • Journey in Tech and SAP:
    Starting in IT during the 1990s, Josh joined SAP in 2007 to manage Blackberries. He witnessed the shift from resisting iPhones to embracing iPads and cloud-first tools. By 2010, SAP was rolling out thousands of iPads, marking a pivotal point in enterprise mobility.

  • Tech Evolution and BTP:
    Josh reflected on SAP’s transition through platforms like CIASE, CYO, and the evolution to SAP’s BTP (Business Technology Platform). He noted how SAP acquired niche technologies, integrated them into core offerings, and expanded their use cases globally—from utility pole workers to cross-network SMS translation.

  • Developer Advocacy and Red Hat Influence:
    A stint at Red Hat exposed Josh to open-source values and meritocracy. Upon returning to SAP, he began training sales teams on cloud tech and Kubernetes. His unique background positioned him to bridge the gap between enterprise solutions and hands-on community engagement.

  • Code Jam São Paulo & LATAM Tour:
    The day before the SIT event, Josh hosted a Code Jam with a hands-on GenAI workshop at X Consulting’s SAP AppHaus. Participants, supported by SAP experts, experimented with SAP’s GenAI tooling and interfaces like Juel. This Code Jam was part of a larger LATAM tour spanning Lima, Mexico City, Bogotá, and more.

  • Community and AI Reflections:
    Despite the buzz around AI, Josh cautioned against losing the human element in tech communities. AI tools can hallucinate and mislead, but it’s the SAP community—people answering questions, organizing meetups, and sharing insights—that keeps the ecosystem vibrant and reliable.

  • DevToberfest and TechEd Highlights:
    Josh promoted DevToberfest, a gamified, month-long learning festival leading into SAP TechEd. It includes live sessions, tutorials, and real-time interaction with SAP experts. He also encouraged participation in DemoJam, offering free entry to TechEd Berlin for selected teams.

  • Empowering Local Engagement:
    Josh emphasized that anyone can become a local event organizer, run SITs, or host SAP meetups—no need to work for SAP. He explained how community members can access support, post events, and receive guidance to grow regional engagement.

  • Closing Thoughts:
    Concluding on a heartfelt note, Josh expressed gratitude for the Brazilian SAP community’s energy and enthusiasm. He praised the volunteer-led spirit of the São Paulo SIT and reiterated his belief in learning through failure, personal storytelling, and community-building.

Final Note:
Josh Bentley’s session was a refreshing reminder that amidst fast-evolving tech trends, it’s the human connections—mentorships, meetups, and shared learning—that sustain innovation. His message was clear: AI might assist, but it’s people who drive the SAP community forward.

entry.title: #SITSP2025DEV 🖥️ Como extrair o melhor do SAP com Fiori e personalizações Clean Core
entry.content:
Palestrante

🗣️Lucas Ferreira

Executivo de contas na Tachyonix, Lucas tem mais de 12 anos de experiência com SAP, tendo atuado como consultor técnico e funcional, pré-vendas e vendedor de soluções BTP. Hoje, ele lidera iniciativas que conectam inovação com resultados práticos em projetos SAP.

 

Descrição da Palestra

Nesta apresentação, Lucas Ferreira compartilhou como o SAP Fiori evoluiu para ser mais que uma interface amigável — ele se tornou a principal porta de entrada para inovação e usabilidade no ecossistema SAP. Com bom humor e analogias simples, Lucas abordou como a experiência do usuário pode ser transformada ao adotar Fiori de maneira estratégica, e como soluções de baixo código (low-code) integradas ao Clean Core agilizam o desenvolvimento de aplicações sem comprometer a governança do sistema.

*** Link com todas as palestras ***

Conteúdo do Blog – Resumo da Palestra

Lucas iniciou sua palestra destacando um contraste: enquanto muitos usuários ainda utilizam o SAP GUI, o verdadeiro valor do SAP S/4HANA está em interfaces modernas e intuitivas como o Fiori. Para demonstrar isso, ele apresentou exemplos visuais e comparações com plataformas populares como Netflix e Facebook, que se tornaram referências de usabilidade por sua padronização e simplicidade.

Ele enfatizou que o SAP Fiori:

  • É intuitivo e padronizado, reduzindo drasticamente o tempo de adoção por novos usuários.

  • Permite combinar funções transacionais e analíticas em uma única interface.

  • É hoje o principal canal para entrega de inovações da SAP, como o assistente digital Joule.

No entanto, Lucas também reconheceu os desafios enfrentados por empresas que precisam de processos customizados, que muitas vezes não são suportados pelos aplicativos Fiori standard. Foi nesse ponto que ele introduziu o conceito de Clean Core, destacando as boas práticas para desenvolvimento e extensibilidade sem comprometer o núcleo do SAP.

A Tachyonix, empresa onde Lucas atua, oferece uma plataforma que permite a criação de apps Fiori, CDS Views e APIs OData dentro do SAP, com uma abordagem low-code, totalmente aderente ao Clean Core. Essa ferramenta reduz significativamente o tempo e o custo de desenvolvimento de aplicações personalizadas.

Exemplos reais foram apresentados, como:

  • Apps desenvolvidos para a Vivo, com entregas 75% mais rápidas do que no modelo tradicional.

  • Soluções para Suzano, Piracanjuba e Bobst, que integraram Fiori com leitura de QR code, anexos e coleta de dados em mobile.

  • Economia de quase R$ 200 mil em 6 meses pela Piracanjuba usando a plataforma da Tachyonix.

Lucas finalizou a apresentação com uma demonstração prática do ambiente da Tachyonix dentro do SAP S/4HANA, exibindo a criação de um app de aprovação de pedidos de compra. Mostrou também dashboards analíticos criados em poucos cliques, ressaltando a importância da convergência entre dados transacionais e analíticos na jornada de transformação digital.

entry.title: One-Click Export-Automating SuccessFactors EC New Hire Integration API Document--Optimization
entry.content:
Hello SuccessFolks

In my previous blog posts, I introduced how to utilize a standard and reusable Python script to:

  1. Extract SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC) metadata with attributes
    One-Click Export: Automating SuccessFactors EC API Metadata to Excel
  2. Generate the standard new hire upsert API documentation
    One-Click Export: Automating SuccessFactors EC Standard New Hire Integration

However, I realized these scripts did not fully address certain integration scenarios and code mapping requirements such as Picklists and MDF values. To bridge these gaps, I’ve enhanced the script with a more structured design.

Note: Because I am concerned that sharing the source code in SAP Community have security risk, please @ME in comment if you are interested and I will share it with you in private.

Enhancement Summary

No. Feature Description

1More Integration ScenariosAdded support for: Report No Show, Hire Data Correction, Rehire with Old Employment, Create New Position before upsert new hire
2API OptimizationImproved handling for Dependent Info upsert API.
Added hard-coded Termination eventReason into upsert body.
Removed unnecessary "EndDate" and "background order" fields.
Added isPrimary filters for Email, Phone, and NationalId entities.
3Code-Value Mapping TableAuto-export of picklist values and MDF dropdown values.
4Postman Collection ExportGenerates a ready-to-import Postman collection for testing and validation.
5Script Refactoring & ImprovementsMerged all scripts into one structured file and externalized configuration file for better security.

This enhancement not only improves functionality and coverage but also makes the script easier to maintain, run independently, and adapt to real-world use cases. Feel free to reach out or comment if you have feedback or further enhancement ideas.

README for Script

Below are the README contents generated to help you understand the features and considerations when implementing these enhancements:

Overview

The SuccessFactors EC API Toolkit is a comprehensive Python utility designed to interact with SuccessFactors OData APIs, extract metadata, process API responses, and generate standardized API documentation. This toolkit consolidates multiple specialized scripts into a single, well-structured application that provides end-to-end functionality for API management and documentation generation for Employee Central (EC) data.

Features

  • API Data Retrieval: Connect to SuccessFactors OData APIs and extract entity data
  • Metadata Extraction: Parse XML metadata to understand API structure and field attributes
  • Code-Value Mapping: Extract and process picklist and MDF values and their mappings
  • Data Enrichment: Combine API data with metadata for comprehensive documentation
  • Document Generation: Create standardized API documentation with proper formatting
  • API Testing: Test API endpoints with sample requests and capture responses
  • Template Management: Update API templates with the latest data and formatting
  • Postman Collection: Generate Postman Collection for API testing

Function Descriptions

Utility Functions

  • get_filter: Generates filter strings for API queries
  • clean_metadata_url: Cleans metadata URLs for proper formatting
  • clean_json: Removes specific keys from JSON data and modifies URLs
  • autofit_and_style: Applies formatting to Excel worksheets (column width, headers, borders)
  • capitalize_headers: Capitalizes header row in Excel worksheets
  • reorder_columns: Reorders columns in Excel worksheets based on a specified order
  • get_valid_sheet_name: Generates valid Excel sheet names (31 character limit)
  • transform_json: Transforms JSON data by replacing specific keys with predefined values
  • remove_blank_values: Removes keys with blank values from dictionaries

XML Metadata Parsing Functions

  • get_text: Extracts text from XML elements
  • get_sap_tags: Extracts SAP-specific tags from XML elements
  • get_attr_value: Gets attribute values from XML elements
  • clean_attr: Cleans attribute values for proper formatting

API Data Retrieval Functions

  • get_ec_api_body: Retrieves API data for specified entity sets
  • extract_ec_odata_api_dictionary: Extracts API metadata dictionary
  • get_code_value: Retrieves and processes code-value mappings

Data Merging and Document Generation Functions

  • enrich_upsert_sheet_with_dictionary: Enriches upsert sheet with dictionary data
  • enrich_api_entity_sheet: Enriches API entity sheet with attribute data
  • clean_upsert_and_api_sample: Cleans upsert data and API sample
  • form_standard_api_document: Forms the standard API document
  • post_valid_bodies_and_export_response: Posts valid bodies to API and exports responses
  • update_api_templates: Updates API templates with the latest data

Main Functions

  • merge_ec_api_and_metadata: Combines steps to merge EC API data with metadata
  • form_standard_api_document_full: Combines steps to form the complete standard API document
  • run_full_pipeline: Runs the complete API toolkit pipeline

Output Files

The toolkit generates several Excel and JSON files during processing:

  • 1.SF EC Table API Attribute.xlsx: Contains EC table API attributes
  • 2.SF New Hire Integration Standard API TemplateV1.xlsx: Contains integration templates and master data
  • 3.SF EC Field API Attribute.xlsx: Contains EC field API attributes and metadata
  • 4.SF New Hire Sample API Upsert.xlsx: Contains API sample upsert data
  • 5.SF New Hire API Post Preview.xlsx: Contains API request bodies and responses
  • 6.SF Dropdown CodeValue Table.xlsx: Contains picklist values and their mappings
  • 7.SF Standard New Hire API DocumentV1.xlsx: Contains enriched API documentation
  • 8.SF New Hire Postman_Collection Excel.xlsx: Contains Postman collection data
  • 9.SF New Hire Postman_Collection.json: Contains Postman collection in JSON format

entry.title: RAP : custom entity and data stream
entry.content:
Hello,

I have a very specific need to implement regarding Attachments.
I have implemented a custom entity (exposed with the alias "Attachments") to retrieve attachments from SAP backend to the FIORI Element app.
I have implemented the SELECT method of the RAP query provider (if_rap_query_provider), where i fill the attachment content along with key fields and file properties (mime type/file name).
When I test the GET request to download the file  (.../Attachments(<attachment_key>)/$value)  it returns nothing as content (the request is successful though / status 200)
In Debug mode, I checked that the SELECT method is being called and the content of the RAWSTRING field is filled with the correct data but i get nothing on the frontend side.

I declared the fields in the custom entity like this : 

@Semantics.largeObject : { 
	mimeType : 'MimeType', 
	fileName : 'FileName' } 
AttachmentContent : abap.rawstring(99999); 

@Semantics.mimeType: true 
MimeType : char128; 

FileName : char128;

I have noticed one other thing, not only the content of the response is empty but response headers also are not correct, i dont get what i expect for these two headers :

content-type : "application/octet-stream" instead of the actuel mime type 

content-disposition : "attachment; filename=entity." instead of the actual file name

What did I missed ? Is it possible to handle attachments using Custom Entities in the first place ?
I found nothing on blogs/internet. All examples i found are based on DDIC-CDS based entities, not Custom Entities.
Thanks a lot for your help 🙂 
Note: I tried using type abap.rawstring(0) for field AttachmentContent but it's not working either

entry.title: Re: Good Recipient cannot generated in mvt 311 when using...
entry.content:
Why the Goods Recipient field Is empty in MIGO 311 with WM Sloc could be due to the following:-

  • When you post a 311 transfer posting between storage locations that are Warehouse Management (WM)-enabled, SAP triggers WM-specific processes (e.g., transfer requirements and transfer orders). These processes do not use the Goods Recipient field from MIGO;  instead, they rely on WM logic for tracking and accountability. In WM-managed locations, the recipient is typically not relevant at the IM level because the goods are tracked by bin and transfer order.
  • Once MIGO posts the 311 movement, SAP creates a Transfer Requirement (TR) and expects the warehouse team to process it via LT06 or LT12. These transactions do not carry forward the Goods Recipient field from MIGO.

If the Goods Recipient field is critical for your process (e.g., for audit or tracking), couple of workarounds are there

  • Consider using non-WM-managed storage locations for 311 postings; this allows full control over IM-level fields.
  • If WM must be used add a custom field or enhancement to capture the Goods Recipient in the Transfer Order (TO). Use user exits or BAdIs (e.g., MWMTO001) to pass the value from MIGO to TO.

entry.title: Re: Source of data for Settlement Doc Pricing
entry.content:
You have raised two questions

  1. Does Split Criteria Control Field Population in Settlement Items?
  2. Do You Need to Append WBRP or Can Pricing Read from Business Volume or CDS?

To answer your first question, Yes, partially. The split criteria in the condition contract settlement process determines which fields from the business volume base are transferred to the settlement item (WBRP). If a field (e.g. Customer Price Group) is part of the split criteria, it will be copied into the settlement item. If it’s not part of the split criteria, it won’t be available in WBRP; and therefore, not usable in pricing unless you enhance the structure. So yes, split criteria is the key control for populating fields in settlement items.
To answer your second question, Standard pricing reads from the settlement item (WBRP); not directly from the business volume table or CDS views. So if your pricing condition (e.g. RCS1 or RCA1) uses fields like Customer Price Group or Material Price Group, those fields must be present in WBRP. Otherwise, the access sequence won’t find the condition record.

What you can do is to append WBRP with the required fields (e.g. KUNNR, MATKL, PRGRP). Include those fields in split criteria so they are populated from business volume. Enhance the business volume CDS view if you need to extract additional fields during volume determination

entry.title: Complex Multi-Rater Performance Rating Overall Calculations in SAP SuccessFactors Integration Center
entry.content:
This blog outlines a solution for calculating complex performance ratings involving multiple rater roles within SAP SuccessFactors PMGM. The methodology leverages a combination of Table Reports, SFTP, Metadata Framework (MDF), and Integration Center, demonstrating the advanced capabilities of the platform’s native tools without requiring custom development. I hope that it could inspire you about the power of combining these tools.

Background

Take below calculation logic as an example:

The standard performance rating calculation logic in SuccessFactors is insufficient when faced with certain complex requirements. The primary challenges addressed by this solution include:

  • Multiple Rater Influence: The overall rating calculation must incorporate input from various rater roles (e.g., Manager, HR, Matrix Manager), with specific weighting for each role being sourced directly from Employee Central.
  • Dynamic Goal/Competency Content: The performance form contains a variable number of goals and competencies, which are organized into multiple distinct categories.
  • Role-Specific Ratings: The final report must reference section-level ratings for each distinct rater role. And the role amount vary in different form.
  • Lack of Identifiers: Standard reporting tools and APIs do not provide a direct identifier for the specific role of the user who entered a rating, making it difficult to differentiate between inputs.

Implementation Details

The solution is implemented in three main stages: data export, data ingestion, and calculation.

Step 1: Exporting Raw Rating Data

The first step is to extract the raw rating data from the performance forms.

  1. Report Creation: Two separate Table Reports are created—one for goal ratings and one for competency ratings. Both reports are configured with an identical data structure to ensure consistency. The key fields include:
    • Subject User ID
    • Form Template ID
    • Document ID
    • Competency/Goal ID
    • Competency/Goal Other Rating (the rating value)
    • Competency/Goal Weight
    • Competency/Goal Other Rating Owner User ID (the rater's ID)
    • Form Start Date
    • Section ID
    • Section Name
  2. Data Filtering: Filters are applied to the reports to exclude irrelevant data, such as deleted forms, unrated items, and non-essential form sections.
  3. Scheduled Export: A daily scheduled job is configured to export the reports as CSV files to a designated SFTP server. It is important to note that Table Reports are essential for this step; the Integration Center cannot be used directly to export all ratings from a performance form as it requires a specific Form Data ID to be provided as a parameter.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Step 2: Ingesting Data via Integration Center

Next, the exported data is consumed and processed.

  1. File Consumption: The SFTP server will contain daily goal and competency files, each appended with a date suffix.
  2. Integration Setup: Two separate Integration Center jobs are configured to process these files. Each job maps the fields from its respective CSV file to a custom MDF object.

Note: The integration must be configured to use the Upsert Single operation. This is mandatory because the process updates a parent-child MDF object structure, and this operation ensures data integrity for both the parent and child records within a single execution.

Step 3: Executing Calculations via MDF Business Rules

The core logic of the solution resides in business rules attached to the custom MDF object. When the Integration Center upserts data into the MDF object, onSave rules are automatically triggered to perform the calculations.

The MDF object is structured with parent and child levels to properly organize the data for calculation. The key fields and logic are detailed below:

MDF Object Field Description

ParentexternalCodeMaps to Subject User ID.
ParentexternalNameMaps to Document ID.
ParenteffectiveStartDateMaps to Form Start Date.
ParentOverallRating, etc.Stores the final calculated ratings for each role and the overall score.
ChildexternalCodeA composite key created from ItemID + RaterUserID.
ChildRoleThe calculated rater role (e.g., EM, EX) based on Job Relationships.
ChildCategoryMaps to the Section Name from the performance form.
ChilditemRatingThe weighted item rating, calculated as Rating * Weight.

Key Business Rule Logic

Several critical business rules drive the automated calculations:

  • Role Type Identification: This rule determines the rater's role by cross-referencing the Rating User ID from the form with the employee's Job Relationship data in Employee Central. A condition is included to prevent the role from being cleared if a rater's job relationship has changed since the form was completed.

  • Role-Specific Section Rating: The solution calculates the section-level rating for each rater role (e.g., Goal Section Rating for the Manager, Competency Section Rating for HR). This is achieved using the Sum of Collection Field Values() function, which aggregates the itemRating values from the child object, filtered by the rater's Role and Category.

  • Overall Rating Calculation: The final, overall rating is computed by applying the appropriate weighting for each rater's section scores. Since these weight proportions are sourced from Employee Central, the business rule includes conditional logic to apply different calculation formulas based on the configuration stored in EC for the subject employee.

Conclusion and Further Applications

This solution successfully automates a complex, multi-rater performance rating calculation by integrating several standard SAP SuccessFactors tools. The final calculated data, stored within the custom MDF object, becomes readily available for analysis and reporting through Canvas and Story reports.

Furthermore, because the performance form's unique Document ID is stored in the MDF object, a subsequent integration can be configured. We could import the calculated overall rating back into the corresponding field on the in-progress performance management form, fully closing the loop on the process and ensuring data consistency across the system.

entry.title: Re: ARM Process Issue
entry.content:
This behavior is likely due to how SAP ARM determines follow-up activities based on material master settings, Return reason, Inspection outcome and customizing in LO-ARM (Advanced Returns Management).
SAP may attempt to create SD2 if it interprets the scenario as a free replacement delivery, even if the refund type is set to Replacement. This can happen if the replacement material is not properly maintained or determined, the inspection result or return reason maps to a follow-up activity that includes SD2 and there’s a fallback logic in ARM that defaults to SD2 when replacement fails.

  • Review your ARM Customizing Sales and Distribution > Advanced Returns Management > Define Follow-Up Activities. Here, check the mapping of return reasons and inspection codes to follow-up activities. Ensure that replacement is correctly assigned and SD2 is not inadvertently triggered.
  • Ensure the replacement material is correctly maintained in the return order. If the material is missing or invalid, SAP may default to SD2 or fail silently.
  • Even if SLG1 is empty, try SM13 for update failures and ST22 for dumps

Based on the standard SAP S/4HANA 2023 TM, there's no delivered web service to split an existing Freight Unit.

Based on the data available the only way to fully automate FU splitting is through custom development, typically by:

entry.title: Re: SAP IBP Inventory - EOQ Key Figures questions
entry.content:
Hi @Andrei_Lupu 

Thank you for reaching out with your EOQ scenario. Let me walk you through it.

Based on SAP IBP best practices and system behaviour, here’s how you should populate the key figures:

  • Enter the demand forecast per planning bucket (e.g., 100,000 pcs per week).
  • Use the holding cost per unit per week, not the total. For example, $0.10 per piece/week.
  • Enter the average cost per replenishment cycle (e.g., $1,500 per order), including fixed freight and GR costs.

Do ensure sure all values are aligned to your weekly time bucket, and that the “Time Varying” flag is correctly enabled in all 3 key figures to reflect seasonal or period-based variation.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Error when upload LTMC PIR with condition in SAP Publ...
entry.content:
Hi @imel_99 

Thank you for the detailed screenshots and explanation.

You seem to be encountering this issue during the LTMC upload of a Purchasing Info Record (PIR) with pricing conditions, where:

  • Manually created PIRs automatically assign PPR0 (Net Price).
  • However, in your LTMC upload, when using PPR0, the system expects PNP0 instead, causing errors unless you include PNP0.

Based on your screenshots and logs, the issue arises because the LTMC upload is using a pricing procedure (ZAB001) that expects condition type PNP0 instead of PPR0 for Net Price.

In contrast, your manual PIR creation likely uses a different procedure or configuration that defaults to PPR0.

To resolve this, the are two available options:

  • Adjust pricing procedure ZAB001 to use PPR0 if that aligns with your standard.
  • Or include PNP0 in your LTMC uploads if PNP0 is the expected net price condition.

You can review this under SPRO à Define Pricing Procedures à ZAB001 and check which conditions are mandatory.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Shared Resource Scenario in PPDS
entry.content:
Hi @Debasis_Nanda 

Thanks for sharing the details. This is one of the classic cases of modelling shared secondary resources in PP/DS.

You can define the hoppers as a multiresource with a total capacity of 6. Then you can use it as a finite secondary resource across both packing lines.

Each operation can then consume a portion of the hoppers (e.g., 2 or 4), and PP/DS will only schedule when the total hopper usage across both lines stays within 6.

It's best to configure this using bucket-based finite scheduling and maintain usage per order operation in the PDS. This allows you to simulate and balance hopper usage while scheduling based on order priority and setup times.

I hope this provides you the necessary details you need. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Can we set multi scaled conditions in SAP TM Rate table?
entry.content:
Hi @LINGLINGLING_CN 

Yes, this requirement can be fulfilled in SAP TM by combining per-FU FOs with aggregated pricing logic.

You’ll need to:

  • Configure your rate table with From Location To Location, and Calendar Day as condition keys
  • Enable charge aggregation in your charge type (set calculation rule to Rate Based, aggregation mode to Day, base = Weight)
  • Define a grouping strategy in your charge calculation sheet to aggregate FO weights by lane and shipping day.

This setup allows you to keep 1 FU = 1 FO while still applying daily consolidated pricing per lane/weight.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Chris

entry.content:
Hi @MahmoudElshall

Thank you for your question

Based on your description it can be confirmed that this is expected behaviour. Please note that once you implement /SCWM/EX_CORE_PTS_NBIN_NRM, SAP no longer applies its standard bin split logic automatically. Hence why a different approach is required.

To enable automatic bin splitting again, you need to manually handle the split inside your BADI implementation:

  • Distribute quantity accordingly in ET_FINAL_BIN

Alternatively, you could explore using BADI /SCWM/EX_CORE_PTS_STRATEGY for more control.

entry.title: Re: Last movement in WH Monitor
entry.content:
Hello @sylwiac &  @hannes_mack 

@sylwiac 

This is a very valid requirement and one that’s come up in several warehouse optimization projects.

Although SAP EWM does not provide this out-of-the-box, you can implement it by:

  • Querying /SCWM/ORDIM_C or /SCWM/ORDIM_H to get the last WT confirmation date for each product in a bin.
  • Filtering for storage types that represent PSA, Quality, or Work Center zones.
  • Building a custom monitor method or Z-report that shows stock along with “last movement date” and calculates the days since last movement.

This approach works well for identifying forgotten inventory and cleaning up long-idle stock.

 

@hannes_mack 

You are right, this feature exists in WM/SRM but not natively in EWM. However, it can be added by enhancing the Warehouse Monitor (/SCWM/MON).

My suggestion is to:

  • Join /SCWM/QUAN and /SCWM/ORDIM_C to get the latest putaway confirmation per bin/product.
  • Use a custom monitor method to calculate the number of days since that movement.
  • Display this value in a new column within the Stock node.

You can use the monitor enhancement framework or alternatively build a report that provides this insight to warehouse supervisors.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Storage bin lock during WT creation after complete pr...
entry.content:
Hello @gerardbuitelaar89 

Thank you for your question.

This is a standard behaviour in EWM when you are using Addition to Existing Stock strategy in a bulk storage type. If a WT is created to a bin but not yet confirmed, the system locks the bin to prevent over-allocation.

Even with the HU check off and capacity check set to 4, EWM still locks the bin for the following reasons:

  • There's an open WT for that bin
  • The system uses a default bin locking mechanism

To resolve this, my suggestion is to:

  • Check for unconfirmed WTs in /SCWM/MON.
  • Confirm existing WTs before creating new ones.
  • Alternatively, consider adjusting your putaway rule or WT creation logic to allow parallel usage of the same bin.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Friends concept in ABAP OO
entry.content:
First you have to understand the concept of an abstract factory pattern. In such a pattern, there is a family of classes, that execute the business logic (they are called products), and then there is a family of factories - their only task is to produce the right class of product. We don't want any developer to create product on their own. Which means that this has to be impossible:

data(product) = new lcl_product_b( ).

The only way to block producing it is to have lcl_product_b created privately:

CLASS lcl_product_b DEFINITION CREATE PRIVATE
  INHERITING FROM lcl_product.
ENDCLASS.

Then the question comes: If it's created private, then how can it be created if it doesn't have a factory method? The answer is: have an abstract factory that is befriended with it.:

INTERFACE lif_factory DEFINITION.

METHODS: create_product RETURNING VALUE(result) TYPE REF TO lcl_product.
ENDINTERFACE.

CLASS lcl_product DEFINITION 
  ABSTRACT 
  CREATE PRIVATE
  FRIENDS lif_factory.
ENDCLASS.

CLASS lcl_product_b DEFINITION
  INHERITING FROM lcl_product. "now product_b is private and also gives it's friendship to all class implementing the factory
ENDCLASS.

CLASS lcl_factory_abs DEFINITION.
PUBLIC SECTION.
interfaces lif_factory.
ENDCLASS.

CLASS lcl_factory_b DEFINITION INHERITING FROM lcl_factory_abs.
PUBLIC SECTION.
methods lif_factory~create_product.
ENDCLASS.

CLASS lcl_factory_b IMPLEMENTATION.
  METHOD lif_factory~create_product.
    result = new lcl_product_b( ). " I can do it only because family of factories are befriended to the family of products
  ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

 

Please mind, that if anyone uses this complex pattern to create one class, they will burn in developer's hell, or will reincarnate as a "html developer".  This pattern is to be used to create a family of various products, where there are many variations of creating such a family. In any other case, the "factory method" pattern is a much better choice.

For example, you need to create a family with:

  • mother
  • father
  • son
  • daughter
  • cat

you create an abstract factory lcl_family_factory (I'm skipping interface for simplicity and laziness 😉

CLASS lcl_family_factory definition abstract.
methods:
create_mother returning value(result) type ref to lcl_mother,
create_father returning value(result) type ref to lcl_father,
create_son returning value(result) type ref to lcl_son,
create_daughter returning value(result) type ref to lcl_daughter,
create_cat returning value(result) type ref to lcl_cat.
ENDCLASS.

This class does nothing, but then you create concrete factories:

  • lcl_nubian_family_factory
  • lcl_mayan_family_factory
  • lcl_inca_family_factory
  • lcl_babylonian_family_factory
  • lcl_slavic_family_factory
  • lcl_viking_family_factory

Now if I want to create a family, I will use one of the concrete factories to get all the products (all members of a family). This way I will always get a consistent family. If I produced each member separately, there would be a risk of my error, so that a Mayan family has a Slavic lynx instead of a puma - imagine how improper would that be. To prevent such mistakes, all the product classes are CREATE PRIVATE and the only way to produce them is through the factory.

Normally in ABAP there's no need for abstract factory, unless you produce your own product.

entry.title: SAP Digital Manufacturing 25.08 Release enhancements and new capabilities
entry.content:
See my personal highlights of SAP Digital Manufacturing 25.08 Release below:

* Subject to change
* This blog post is Work In Progress and will be constantly updated in the upcoming days during the release cycle, so make sure you come back often to check the updates. 

Do you like this content? Please live a Kudos!

Dynamic Topics in Subscriptions and in the Publish MQTT Message Service

You can use free text to define the topic where your MQTT message will be published when creating indicator and message type subscriptions in the Manage Automatic Triggers app. A similar feature also applies to the Publish MQTT Message service of the Design Production Processes app. You can use parameters, variables, and expressions, in addition to free text.

To use this feature, make sure you are using Production Connector on Windows or Production Connector on edge, both with version 2.6.0 or higher. 

More information:

  • Available Services and Subprocesses
  • Manage Subscriptions
  • Create a Subscription

Data Collection

  • Added List to the parameter Type field in the Manage Data Collection app. You can use the List type to choose the required data field for your parameter from the list of data fields displayed in the Select Data Field page through a value help.
  • For Boolean type parameters, you can set a default True / False value while creating the parameter in the Manage Data Collection app. The set value is selected by default and is displayed in the segment button in the Data Collection POD plugin.
  • Certain special characters are supported while defining the Data Collection Group Name, Version, and Parameter Name in the Manage Data Collection app.

Bulk Component Add Integration

Previously, if you didn't configure the collaboration link COLLABORATION_SFC_COMPONENT_ADD, the assembly of non-EWM components was integrated with your ERP system during SFC completion. This happened through the Production Order Yield Confirmation message and/or the Production Order Scrap Confirmation message if you configured the collaboration links COLLABORATION_ERP_YIELD_CONFIRMATION and/or COLLABORATION_ERP_SCRAP_CONFIRMATION. You can still use this integration scenario where the 261 goods movement is part of the yield or scrap integration message.

Now, if you configure the collaboration link COLLABORATION_BULK_COMPONENT_ADD with the collaboration directive ERP_BULK_COMPONENT_ADD, the assembly of these components integrates with your ERP system during SFC completion through the Production Order Bulk Component Add message. The Production Order Yield Confirmation and Production Order Scrap Confirmation messages only integrate the yield and scrap data, respectively. So, in this scenario, which lets you bulk add components, the 261 goods movement data is no longer contained in the yield or scrap messages.

You need to set up the following elements for this integration scenario:

  • COLLABORATION_BULK_COMPONENT_ADD collaboration link / ERP_BULK_COMPONENT_ADD collaboration directive in the Manage Collaboration Links app.

  • Bulk Add Production Order Component integration flow in SAP Cloud Integration

More information: Manage Collaboration Links and Manage Collaboration Directives

Configuring Production Processes for Packing

You can set up the system to trigger production processes during packing when you choose Add or Pack in the Packing List plugin in the POD. To do this, assign production processes to one or more of the following configuration options of the Packing List plugin in the POD Designer app:
  • Production Process Before the Pack Action
  • Production Process After the Pack Action
  • Production Process After the Add Action
 
More information: Production Processes Executed During Packing

Custom Fields in the Operation Activity List

In POD Designer, you can configure the Operation Activity List plugin to display custom fields defined for routing operations in the operation activity list of your POD.

More information: Operation Activity List

Enable SFC-Based Scheduling

You can enable SFC-based scheduling in the Manage Business Settings app, allowing you to plan and track of operations for each SFC in the Dispatching and Monitoring app.

More information: Scheduling.

Learn more about SFC-Based Scheduling at:

  • SFC-Based Dispatching in Resource Orchestration
  • SFC-Based Dispatching in REO: Granular Production Scheduling and Process Industry Support

Filter Operation Activity List by Resource

Added a configuration called Filter by Resource to the Operation Activity List plugin. When set to On, operation activities are filtered by a specific resource, if provided. The default value is Off.

More information: Operation Activity List

Usability Improvements for the Manage Orders App


Improved the user interface of the Manage Orders app:

  • In the Adapt Filters menu, you can access the search functionality.

  • The release and execution statuses are semantically color-coded.

More information: Manage Orders

Order Report

You can filter records based on the material description using the Material value help.

More information: Order Report

SFC Report

  • You can filter records based on the material description using the Material value help, batch number, storage location, and components.

  • You can view batch number and storage location in the General section of the SFC details page.

  • The Components tab in the SFC details page is enhanced to display non-BOM components in addition to the BOM components.

More information: SFC Report

Manufacturing Data Objects (MDOs)

The following events are supported by the SFCProductionEvents MDO:

  • SFC_HOLD
  • SFC_HOLD_RELEASED

The HoldComment attribute has been added to the SFCProductionEvents MDO.

Cloud Event Deprecations

In the upcoming 2602 release, several cloud events will be deprecated in the business rules in the Manage Automatic Triggers app. New events have been introduced in this release to replace the deprecated ones. The following list displays the deprecated events along with their substitutes.

This deprecation announcement is effective starting from the 2602 release. The new events are available from the 2508 release.

  • Existing Event: SFC Started - v2
    Substitute Event: SFC Started - v3
  • Existing Event: SFC Yield - v1
    Substitute Event: SFC Yield - v2
  • Existing Event: SFC Split - v1
    Substitute Event: SFC Split - v2
  • Existing Event: SFCs Merged - v1
    Substitute Event: SFCs Merged - v2
  • Existing Event: SFCs Relabeled - v1
    Substitute Event: SFCs Relabeled - v2
  • Existing Event: SFCs Serialized - v1
    Substitute Event: SFCs Serialized - v2
  • Existing Event: SFC Operation Activity Started - v1
    Substitute Event: SFC Operation Activity Started - v2
  • Existing Event: SFC Operation Activity Completed - v1
    Substitute Event: SFC Operation Activity Completed - v2

Starting from the 2602 release, the SFC Created - v1 cloud event will be deprecated and removed from the Manage Automatic Triggers app. Update any business rules that use this event by replacing it with Order Released - v3.

More information: Manage Automatic Triggers.

Specific Business Services Deprecation

Starting from the 2602 release, the below business services will be deprecated. In the Manage Automatic Triggers app, the following business services will no longer appear as options in the Business Service dropdown menu under the Business Rules tab.

  • Complete Operation Activity - v1
  • Complete Phase - v1
  • Complete SFC - v1
  • Final quantity confirmation on completed operation activity - v1
  • Merge SFC - v1
  • Production Change - v1
  • Quantity Confirmation - v1
  • Relabel SFC - v1
  • Serialize SFC - v1
  • Set quantity SFC - v1
  • Split SFC - v1
  • Start Operation Activity - v1
  • Start Phase - v1
  • Start SFC - v1

Deprecation of the Overlay Authoring Tool and Associated Plugins

The Overlay Authoring Tool has been deprecated, along with the following associated plugins:

  • Line Monitor Fill Color
  • Line Monitor Image Overlay

Changes to Identity and Access Management

We're continuing to improve role template definition by restricting view access to apps that show data not required by certain personas. We're making these changes to improve overall usability.

The following default PODs are no longer included on the default Fiori launchpad for all personas:
  • Work Center POD (Default)
  • Order POD (Default)
  • Operation Activity POD (Default)
  • Post Production Reporting POD (Default)
  • Line Monitor POD (Default)
In addition, we're removing the following role templates:
  • Automation_Technical_User
  • Plant_Manager
  • Global_Regional_Manager
  • Alert_Monitor_User

For detailed information, refer to SAP Note 3618884.

Change Production

To make sure that activity confirmation data is covered in production change scenarios, we've introduced the ActivityConfirmationCopy flag in the Production Order Download (LOIPRO05 V2) integration workflow.

By default, this flag is set to 'false'. If set to 'true', the activity confirmation data is copied from operation activities belonging to the old routing to the new routing after the production change has taken place.

More information: Updating Orders After the Release for Production Order (Custom XSLT)

New and Changed API Endpoints

Data Collection

  • POST /datacollection/v1/nonwip/uploadFile: You can use this endpoint to upload and securely store non-WIP data collection files during the data logging process.
  • The GET /measurements endpoint in the Data Collection API must be used only for normal data collection requirements. For non-WIP data collection, you must use the GET /nonwip/measurements endpoint in the Standalone / Non-WIP Data Collection API.
  • The following fields are added to the GET /groups, POST /groups, PUT /groups and GET /sfc/groups endpoints in the Data Collection API:
    • defaultValueName: Allows you to set a default true / false value while creating a data collection parameter.
    • listTypeDataField: Allows you to choose the required data field for your data collection parameter from the list of data fields.
  • The V1 and V2 versions of the Setpoint Activities API are decommissioned. Start using the V3 version of the API.

Labor

  • POST /labors/shift-assignment: This endpoint allows production supervisors to assign specific shifts and optional work centers to the workforce within a plant for a defined date range. More information: Labor.

  • GET /labor/v1/LaborSkills: This OData V4 API endpoint fetches the skillsets of a workforce under a production supervisor’s scope. More information: Labor.

Setpoint Activities

Added the enableStrictFilter header parameter as an optional parameter to the GET /find endpoint in the Setpoint Activities API. You can now specify the way filters are applied to the setpoints.

More information: Setpoint Activities

Shop Floor Control Production Activities

Added the parameters includeSFCDetails and sfcStatuses to the Shop Floor Control Production Activities API.

The includeSFCDetails parameter is available for the GET /worklist/orders endpoint, and allows you to control if SFC details are retrieved for each order. When includeSFCDetails is set to true, SFC details are retrieved. When it is set to false, no SFC details are retrieved.

 
The sfcStatuses parameter allows you to filter results by SFC status for the following endpoints:

  • GET /worklist/sfcs

  • GET /worklist/orders

  • GET /worklist/sfcs/$count

  • GET /worklist/orders/$count

More information: Shop Floor Control Production Activities and https://api.sap.com/api/sapdme_sfc/resource/Production_Details

Inventory

You can clear inventories for given plants and inventory IDs by using the following endpoint of the Inventory API:
  • POST/api/v1/inventories/clear

    The quantity on hand for specified inventories is set to zero once they're cleared.

You can conduct specific quantity filtering of the stock quantity on hand by using the quantityOnHandFilter field and the following endpoint of the Inventory API:
  • POST/api/v1/inventories/advancedQuery

You can use the bomComponentSequence field in the following endpoints of the Inventory API:

    • POST /inventory/erpGoodsReceipts
    • POST /inventory/ewmGoodsReceipts
    • GET /inventory/goodsReceipts/summarize

      The bomComponentSequence field allows you to precisely identify BOM components of different types (for example, normal, co-product, and by-product) while supporting consistent goods receipt integration with ERP and EWM. This allows you to avoid confusion when the same material has been set up as normal type of BOM component and also as a co- or by-product.

More information: Inventory

And much more! See What´s New for more details.

 
* Subject to change
* This blog post is Work In Progress and will be constantly updated in the upcoming days during the release cycle, so make sure you come back often to check the updates. 
 
Do you like this content? Please live a Kudos!
If you have any questions, please check SAP Community Q&A Area, or comment down below.

Thanks,
Manoel Costa

entry.title: Stream with CAP Node JS
entry.content:
Hello,
I've implemented a very simplistic CAP service that sends a request to a SAP S4 backend system to retrieve a file as a stream ( .../$value)

This a simplified version of my code in the request handler function :

const results = await _sendAxiosHttpRequest(
            {
                method: "GET",
                url: "<service_path>/$value",
                headers: oHeaders,
                responseType: "stream",
                maxContentLength: Infinity,
                maxBodyLength: Infinity
            },
            <my_destination>);
    
 return [{ value: results.data,
           $mediaContentType: results.headers["content-type"],
           $mediaContentDispositionType: results.headers["content-disposition"] }];

As you can see, i send the request using Axios and in debug mode I checked that this request to the S/4 backend is successful.
results.data is an object of type IncomingMessage (which is a readable stream)
The problem is that the response generated by the CAP service contains nothing. It returns an empty response. 
Even the headers "content-type" and "content-disposition" are not set.

Do you have any Idea, why it's not working ?

Thank you for your help 🙂

entry.title: Re: Cloud ERP & Primavera
entry.content:
Hi there — ran into a similar challenge recently while supporting a hybrid cloud ERP setup.

While direct reference cases for S/4HANA Public Cloud + Primavera P6 are limited (especially on the public customer side), most integration scenarios we’ve worked with use middleware like SAP BTP or CPI, leveraging iDocs/XML for schedule and cost data sync. You might also consider intermediate staging via flat files + RFC/ODATA when APIs are too limited on either end.

We had a similar case at Phonexa, integrating multiple SaaS platforms with different data schemas — biggest lesson: plan early for data ownership, sync frequency, and fallback handling.

Would also recommend checking SAP Note 2769657 and related threads in the SAP Project Systems tag — a few users posted workarounds there.

Hope that helps!

entry.title: Re: Blog Series: S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition – 03 Advanced Intercompany Sales & Material Stock
entry.content:
Thanks for the excellent blog Bimal, very informative.

Just a quick note: in the section

"When the shipment reaches the Port or CFS of Newark, US as per the DDP incoterm the actual external control date in delivery should be updated. This initiates the Goods Issue from Stock-In Transit (at Plant 1710) and transfers the risk to the customer. For demo purposes, the external control date is updated to the current date (9th July) and the system automatically generated the material document (4900000193) with movement type 601 to Goods issue the Stock-In-Transit."

There is a small error the doc is 4900000194
